title: 109_hr3672
content: The Act titled "TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005" allows for the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 authorizes the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, bypassing the usual procedures outlined in the Social Security Act. Additionally, the Act extends the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program activities through December 31, 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 extends TANF Block Grant Program activities through December 31, 2005, with appropriations authorized for fiscal year 2005 continuing until December 31, 2005. Grants and payments can be made through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 extends TANF Block Grant Program activities through December 31, 2005. Amendments are made for supplemental grants, contingency fund, and maintenance of effort for fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 extends TANF Block Grant Program activities through December 31, 2005 with amendments for supplemental grants, contingency fund, and maintenance of effort for fiscal year 2006. Amendments include changes to the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 extends activities authorized by sections 429A and 1130(a) of the Social Security Act through December 31, 2005, with appropriations for fiscal year 2005 and the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. SEC. 3. Reimbursement of states for TANF benefits provided to assist families affected by Hurricane Katrina from other states. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until August 31, 2006, a State qualifies as needy for section 403(b) of the Social Security Act if they have provided short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits to families affected by Hurricane Katrina in another State declared a major disaster area. The State qualifies as needy for section 403(b) of the Social Security Act if a family has resided in a State affected by Hurricane Katrina, traveled to another State due to the hurricane, and is not receiving cash benefits from any other State program. The State qualifies as needy for section 403(b) of the Social Security Act if a family affected by Hurricane Katrina has relocated to another State and is not receiving cash benefits from any other State program. The total amount of funding to a needy State shall not exceed the cash benefits provided to the families involved. No State match is required for this funding. The State qualifies as needy for section 403(b) of the Social Security Act if a family affected by Hurricane Katrina has relocated to another State and is not receiving cash benefits from any other State program. Payment made to a State under this section does not require a State match as per sections 403(b)(6) and 409(a)(10) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 4. Availability of additional TANF funds for hurricane-damaged states. Certain States like Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act until the end of fiscal year 2006. The total loan amount for these states cannot exceed 20 percent of the State family assistance grant for fiscal year 2006. Additionally, these loans can be forgiven under certain conditions. The forgiveness of loans provision under the Social Security Act states that penalties cannot be imposed on Louisiana, Mississippi, or Alabama for failing to repay loans or make interest payments on loans made under the Act between the enactment date and October 1, 2007. SEC. 5 allows States or tribes to use unspent TANF funds to support needy families affected by Hurricane Katrina without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 6 states that work requirements and time limits under the TANF program are not triggered by families receiving temporary TANF benefits due to the hurricane. SEC. 6 exempts families affected by Hurricane Katrina from work requirements and time limits under the TANF program when receiving temporary benefits. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states of Louisiana, Mississippi, or Alabama for non-compliance with certain provisions due to Hurricane Katrina or state's efforts to assist victims. Each amount provided in this Act is designated as an emergency requirement pursuant to section 402 of H. Con. Res. 95 (109th Congress).
